values.description:
This version of the library should allow to publish/subscribe messages between nodes. The messages are typed and if the nodes are within the same process, no serialization should be done.

Requires: zeromq, czmq, robot_msgs, protobuf, and uuid-dev. It also requires c++11 (as probably most of the ignition projects).
values.title: Initial version

summary.raw:

values.description:
This version of the library should allow to publish/subscribe messages between nodes and make synchronous and asynchronous service call requests. The messages are typed and if the nodes are within the same process, no serialization should be done.

Requires: zeromq, czmq, robot_msgs, protobuf, and uuid-dev. It also requires c++11 (as probably most of the ignition projects).

Take a look at src/Node_TEST to see how to use the library while I'm writing the tutorials.

From a design point of view, these are the building blocks I've used to create a node in each process.

```
 _______   _______
|       | |       |
| Node 1| | Node 2|
|_______| |_______|
|                 |
|   Node Shared   |
|_________________|
|                 |
|     Discovery   |
|_________________|
     (Process1)
```

This is the [drone.io
job status](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign_transport).

[![Build Status](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign_transport/status.png)](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign_transport/latest)
values.title: Initial complete version

Take a look at src/Node_TEST to see how to use the library while I'm writing the tutorials.

From a design point of view, these are the building blocks I've used to create a node in each process.

values.description:
Notes:

 * Uuid own implementation with the windows API
 * VS2013 is buggy with initializer list on maps, I made them explicit 
 * There was a [problem](https://connect.microsoft.com/VisualStudio/feedback/details/753115/steady-clock-class-and-clock-function-are-non-conformant-with-c-11-and-c11-standards) with steady_clocks in VS2013 and c++11
 * Implement the cmake variable `CPPZMQ_HEADER_PATH` to help cppzmq detection
 * setenv is not POSIX, implement it for windows.

I will submit a different PR for the port of the test suite.
values.title: Support for windows compilation

summary.raw:
Notes:

 * Uuid own implementation with the windows API
 * VS2013 is buggy with initializer list on maps, I made them explicit 
 * There was a [problem](https://connect.microsoft.com/VisualStudio/feedback/details/753115/steady-clock-class-and-clock-function-are-non-conformant-with-c-11-and-c11-standards) with steady_clocks in VS2013 and c++11
 * Implement the cmake variable `CPPZMQ_HEADER_PATH` to help cppzmq detection
 * setenv is not POSIX, implement it for windows.

I will submit a different PR for the port of the test suite.
summary.html:
Notes:

  • Uuid own implementation with the windows API
  • VS2013 is buggy with initializer list on maps, I made them explicit
  • There was a problem with steady_clocks in VS2013 and c++11
  • Implement the cmake variable CPPZMQ_HEADER_PATH to help cppzmq detection
  • setenv is not POSIX, implement it for windows.

I will submit a different PR for the port of the test suite.

values.description:
Implemented a method for getting fork-like running on windows (it can not work with functions, just running binaries). The full thing should compile, although runtime problems still exists.

* [drone is happy](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/198) on Linux.
* [jenkins is not so happy, but compilation is fine](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-windows7-i386/76/console) on Windows.

Update: merged with default in 9effa61

* [drone is happy](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/233) on Linux.
* [windows jenkins job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-windows7-i386/80/console): compilation passes with warning; some tests are failing.
* [mac jenkins job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ignition_transport/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/17/): compilation is fine with no warnings; it says all tests passed, though the console output seems to indicate that one test failed.

Update 99d4d64:

* [drone is happy](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/246)
* [windows is improving](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-windows7-i386/82/consoleFull): 19% tests passed, 21 tests failed out of 26
* [homebrew is happy](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ignition_transport/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/19/)
* Yes, there is a problem in one of the tests. issue #21.
values.title: Windows: compile tests and examples (take II)

Implemented a method for getting fork-like running on windows (it can not work with functions, just running binaries). The full thing should compile, although runtime problems still exists.

  • drone is happy on Linux.
  • jenkins is not so happy, but compilation is fine on Windows.

Update: merged with default in 9effa61

  • drone is happy on Linux.
  • windows jenkins job: compilation passes with warning; some tests are failing.
  • mac jenkins job: compilation is fine with no warnings; it says all tests passed, though the console output seems to indicate that one test failed.

Update 99d4d64:

  • drone is happy
  • windows is improving: 19% tests passed, 21 tests failed out of 26
  • homebrew is happy
  • Yes, there is a problem in one of the tests. issue #21.

values.description:
This pull request includes a variety of fixes for Windows, including a native implementation of IP address determination.  With these changes in place, I'm able to build and run a unit test from `haptix_comm`.

I already merged from the `multicast` branch and resolved conflicts, so this PR should land after that one has landed.  Alternatively, this PR could be targeted at the `multicast` branch.
values.title: (Merge #25 first) Various Windows fixes

summary.raw:
This pull request includes a variety of fixes for Windows, including a native implementation of IP address determination.  With these changes in place, I'm able to build and run a unit test from `haptix_comm`.

I already merged from the `multicast` branch and resolved conflicts, so this PR should land after that one has landed.  Alternatively, this PR could be targeted at the `multicast` branch.
summary.html:
This pull request includes a variety of fixes for Windows, including a native implementation of IP address determination. With these changes in place, I'm able to build and run a unit test from haptix_comm.

I already merged from the multicast branch and resolved conflicts, so this PR should land after that one has landed. Alternatively, this PR could be targeted at the multicast branch.

values.description:
The changes:

* Make the discovery (de)serialization code safe for 32-bit systems, which we encountered because on Windows we're building 32-bit (the same problem would arise on 32-bit Linux).  Previously, we were using `sizeof(size_t)` during (de)serialization, implicitly assuming that it's 8 bytes.  Note that, along the way we have changed the wire protocol in at least one place (by sending the topic scope as a single byte, instead of the size of its `enum` representation, which could vary).
* Explicitly join the multicast group when setting up discovery.  This is needed on Windows to receive any multicast packets.  And it's the right thing to do, anyway.
* Avoid a crash on shutdown by adding a sleep where we can't join threads because of a Windows bug.
* Add the ability to configure for Release or Debug, including selection of the appropriate underlying protobuf library.  This is important on Windows, where you need to have either all Release or all Debug libraries, all the way down.
* Add CMake infrastructure for compiling the code in `example`.  As we've been doing elsewhere, we're copying around a lot of common CMake code, and also propagating dependencies further than we should (e.g., a program using ign-transport should not have to contain any logic for finding or linking against zmq), but that can be cleaned up later.
values.title: More fixes from Windows development

summary.raw:
The changes:

* Make the discovery (de)serialization code safe for 32-bit systems, which we encountered because on Windows we're building 32-bit (the same problem would arise on 32-bit Linux).  Previously, we were using `sizeof(size_t)` during (de)serialization, implicitly assuming that it's 8 bytes.  Note that, along the way we have changed the wire protocol in at least one place (by sending the topic scope as a single byte, instead of the size of its `enum` representation, which could vary).
* Explicitly join the multicast group when setting up discovery.  This is needed on Windows to receive any multicast packets.  And it's the right thing to do, anyway.
* Avoid a crash on shutdown by adding a sleep where we can't join threads because of a Windows bug.
* Add the ability to configure for Release or Debug, including selection of the appropriate underlying protobuf library.  This is important on Windows, where you need to have either all Release or all Debug libraries, all the way down.
* Add CMake infrastructure for compiling the code in `example`.  As we've been doing elsewhere, we're copying around a lot of common CMake code, and also propagating dependencies further than we should (e.g., a program using ign-transport should not have to contain any logic for finding or linking against zmq), but that can be cleaned up later.
summary.html:
The changes:

  • Make the discovery (de)serialization code safe for 32-bit systems, which we encountered because on Windows we're building 32-bit (the same problem would arise on 32-bit Linux). Previously, we were using sizeof(size_t) during (de)serialization, implicitly assuming that it's 8 bytes. Note that, along the way we have changed the wire protocol in at least one place (by sending the topic scope as a single byte, instead of the size of its enum representation, which could vary).
  • Explicitly join the multicast group when setting up discovery. This is needed on Windows to receive any multicast packets. And it's the right thing to do, anyway.
  • Avoid a crash on shutdown by adding a sleep where we can't join threads because of a Windows bug.
  • Add the ability to configure for Release or Debug, including selection of the appropriate underlying protobuf library. This is important on Windows, where you need to have either all Release or all Debug libraries, all the way down.
  • Add CMake infrastructure for compiling the code in example. As we've been doing elsewhere, we're copying around a lot of common CMake code, and also propagating dependencies further than we should (e.g., a program using ign-transport should not have to contain any logic for finding or linking against zmq), but that can be cleaned up later.

values.description: In the presence of multiple interfaces up, INADDR_ANY lets the kernel to choose the default interface. This change forces the interface to be the one returned by `determineHost()`.
values.title: Specifying the interface for receiving multicast messages

summary.raw: In the presence of multiple interfaces up, INADDR_ANY lets the kernel to choose the default interface. This change forces the interface to be the one returned by `determineHost()`.
summary.html: In the presence of multiple interfaces up, INADDR_ANY lets the kernel to choose the default interface. This change forces the interface to be the one returned by determineHost().

values.description:
A partition is a string identifier used to isolate a node from others and avoid crosstalking. You can specify the partition name in the `Node()` constructor or using the `IGN_PARTITION` environment variable.

For testing you can try running from the `example` directory:

`IGN_PARTITION=private ./publisher`

`IGN_PARTITION=private ./subscriber`

`./subscriber`

Only one of the subscribers should receive the messages.
values.title: Adding partitions to isolate topics and services

summary.raw:
A partition is a string identifier used to isolate a node from others and avoid crosstalking. You can specify the partition name in the `Node()` constructor or using the `IGN_PARTITION` environment variable.

For testing you can try running from the `example` directory:

`IGN_PARTITION=private ./publisher`

`IGN_PARTITION=private ./subscriber`

`./subscriber`

Only one of the subscribers should receive the messages.
summary.html:
A partition is a string identifier used to isolate a node from others and avoid crosstalking. You can specify the partition name in the Node() constructor or using the IGN_PARTITION environment variable.

For testing you can try running from the example directory:

IGN_PARTITION=private ./publisher

IGN_PARTITION=private ./subscriber

./subscriber

Only one of the subscribers should receive the messages.

values.description:
It requires [this](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-tools/pull-requests/1) pull request.

Each Ignition library should install a `.yaml` file and a `.rb` file. The `.yaml` file contains metadata about the commands that are exposed in the library. As an example, I have implemented `ign topic list` and `ign service list` in ignition-transport.

There are a few C functions that are included in the library to interact with the ruby script:

  * Version(): Returns the library version.
  * cmdTopicList(): Implements `ign topic -l [--list]`
  * cmdServiceList(): Implements `ign service -l [--list]`

How do I test it? 

* Go to the `example/` directory and run a `responser`. Then, type `ign service -l`.
* Go to the `example/` directory and run a `publisher`. Then, type `ign topic -l`.

And of course you can poke around with any other option.
values.title: Initial layout for being able to execute transport command line commands with `ign`.

summary.raw:
It requires [this](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-tools/pull-requests/1) pull request.

Each Ignition library should install a `.yaml` file and a `.rb` file. The `.yaml` file contains metadata about the commands that are exposed in the library. As an example, I have implemented `ign topic list` and `ign service list` in ignition-transport.

There are a few C functions that are included in the library to interact with the ruby script:

  * Version(): Returns the library version.
  * cmdTopicList(): Implements `ign topic -l [--list]`
  * cmdServiceList(): Implements `ign service -l [--list]`

How do I test it? 

* Go to the `example/` directory and run a `responser`. Then, type `ign service -l`.
* Go to the `example/` directory and run a `publisher`. Then, type `ign topic -l`.

And of course you can poke around with any other option.
summary.html:
It requires this pull request.

Each Ignition library should install a .yaml file and a .rb file. The .yaml file contains metadata about the commands that are exposed in the library. As an example, I have implemented ign topic list and ign service list in ignition-transport.

There are a few C functions that are included in the library to interact with the ruby script:

  • Version(): Returns the library version.
  • cmdTopicList(): Implements ign topic -l [--list]
  • cmdServiceList(): Implements ign service -l [--list]

How do I test it?

  • Go to the example/ directory and run a responser. Then, type ign service -l.
  • Go to the example/ directory and run a publisher. Then, type ign topic -l.

And of course you can poke around with any other option.

values.description:

This pull request leaves `DiscoveryPrivate` only with member variables. All the methods have been moved to the `Discovery` class.
values.title: DiscoveryPrivate refactor

This will start a series of pull request that will improve the design of the library before starting with the integration in Gazebo.

This pull request leaves `DiscoveryPrivate` only with member variables. All the methods have been moved to the `Discovery` class.

This pull request leaves DiscoveryPrivate only with member variables. All the methods have been moved to the Discovery class.

values.description:
The partition information was included in the topic name. This is an implementation detail that shouldn't affect how the users perceive its topic names.

Here, we remove the partition part from all the topic names that are passed to the callbacks that the users register. Also, the partition part is removed from the methods `GetAdvertisedTopics()`. `GetAdvertisedServices()` and `GetSubscribedTopics()`.
values.title: Hide partitions in topics to the users

summary.raw:
The partition information was included in the topic name. This is an implementation detail that shouldn't affect how the users perceive its topic names.

Here, we remove the partition part from all the topic names that are passed to the callbacks that the users register. Also, the partition part is removed from the methods `GetAdvertisedTopics()`. `GetAdvertisedServices()` and `GetSubscribedTopics()`.
summary.html:
The partition information was included in the topic name. This is an implementation detail that shouldn't affect how the users perceive its topic names.

Here, we remove the partition part from all the topic names that are passed to the callbacks that the users register. Also, the partition part is removed from the methods GetAdvertisedTopics(). GetAdvertisedServices() and GetSubscribedTopics().

values.description:
* Renaming the external C function from `Version()` to `IgnitionVersion()`. The motivation for this change is to avoid possible name collisions. Note that this symbol won't be decorated.

* Moving `IgnitionVersion` implementation to the cpp. Having the implementation in the header file was causing a multiple definition linking error (discovered compiling `handsim` code).
values.title: Move version() to the .cpp file to avoid multiple definition of the symbol.

summary.raw:

values.description: As part of the stress test, we're using an external process that spawns a service responser. We were using `getchar()` to keep the responser alive until the stress test finalizes. This was causing problems while running the test on Drone.io and Jenkins. The workwaround is to replace the `getchar` with a `sleep`.
values.title: Fix stress test in Drone.io/Jenkins

summary.raw: As part of the stress test, we're using an external process that spawns a service responser. We were using `getchar()` to keep the responser alive until the stress test finalizes. This was causing problems while running the test on Drone.io and Jenkins. The workwaround is to replace the `getchar` with a `sleep`.

values.description:
This pull requests tries to fix the remaining issues when running tests locally, in `drone.io`, and in Jenkins.

* Every time a test is executed it creates a random partition name. If the test needs an aux process, the partition name is passed as an argument. This will avoid cross talking between tests.
* Deadlock found and fixed between Discovery and NodeShared.
* Fix `ign_TEST` problem when using partitions.
* Minor tweaks in other tests.

CI results:

* [Drone](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/388) is happy.
* [Jenkins Ubuntu Trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ignition_transport/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-trusty-amd64/20/) is happy.
* [Jenkins Homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ignition_transport/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/42/) is happy.
* [Jenkins Windows7-AMD64](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ignition_transport/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-windows7-amd64/27/) is happy.
* [Jenkins Windows7-i386](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ignition_transport/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-windows7-i386/123/) is happy.

Note that the happiness for the Windows node is just to be able to compile. It's OK for now if the tests fail because we haven't figured out a way to run the tests on Windows yet.
values.title: Fix tests

summary.raw:
This pull requests tries to fix the remaining issues when running tests locally, in `drone.io`, and in Jenkins.

* Every time a test is executed it creates a random partition name. If the test needs an aux process, the partition name is passed as an argument. This will avoid cross talking between tests.
* Deadlock found and fixed between Discovery and NodeShared.
* Fix `ign_TEST` problem when using partitions.
* Minor tweaks in other tests.

CI results:

* [Drone](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/388) is happy.
* [Jenkins Ubuntu Trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ignition_transport/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-trusty-amd64/20/) is happy.
* [Jenkins Homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ignition_transport/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/42/) is happy.
* [Jenkins Windows7-AMD64](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ignition_transport/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-windows7-amd64/27/) is happy.

Note that the happiness for the Windows node is just to be able to compile. It's OK for now if the tests fail because we haven't figured out a way to run the tests on Windows yet.
summary.html:
This pull requests tries to fix the remaining issues when running tests locally, in drone.io, and in Jenkins.

  • Every time a test is executed it creates a random partition name. If the test needs an aux process, the partition name is passed as an argument. This will avoid cross talking between tests.
  • Deadlock found and fixed between Discovery and NodeShared.
  • Fix ign_TEST problem when using partitions.
  • Minor tweaks in other tests.

CI results:

  • Drone is happy.
  • Jenkins Ubuntu Trusty is happy.
  • Jenkins Homebrew is happy.
  • Jenkins Windows7-AMD64 is happy.
  • Jenkins Windows7-i386 is happy.

Note that the happiness for the Windows node is just to be able to compile. It's OK for now if the tests fail because we haven't figured out a way to run the tests on Windows yet.

values.description:
I would prefer to comment this block instead of removing it. When we start using a real logging system we'll write a warning message in a log file. For now I don't want to bother users with this type of messages.

[drone.io](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/418) is happy.
values.title: Removing warning message.
